sections.title: Syntax
sections.text_content: randint ( var i : int, low, high : int )

sections.title: Description
sections.raw_content: The randint statement is used to create a pseudo-random integer in the range low to high, inclusive. For example, if i is an integer, after randint(i,1, 10), i would have a value such as 7 or 2 or 10.

sections.mdown_content: The **randint** statement is used to create a pseudo-random integer in the range *low* to *high*, inclusive. For example, if *i* is an integer, after **randint**(*i*,1, 10), *i* would have a value such as 7 or 2 or 10.

sections.title: Example
code:
var roll : int
        loop
            randint ( i, 1, 6 )
            put "Rolled ", i
        end loop
sections.raw_content: This program simulates the repeated rolling of a six sided die.
sections.text_content: This program simulates the repeated rolling of a six sided die.
sections.mdown_content: This program simulates the repeated rolling of a six sided die.

sections.title: Details
sections.raw_content:
The randint statement sets its parameter to the next value of a sequence of pseudo-random integers that approximates a uniform distribution over the range low =i = high. It is required that low = high.

Each time a program runs, randint uses the same pseudo-random number sequence. To get a different sequence (actually, to start the sequence at a different point), use the randomize procedure.

To use several sequences of repeatable pseudo-random number sequences, use the randseed and randnext procedures.
